B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

The Policy and Enabling Environment 

A conducive policy environment is vital for SMEs to flourish, and contribute to economic 
12. 
growth  and  employment.  That  generally  means  clear,  predictable,  and  simple  rules  regarding 
licensing, registration, taxation, and collateral registration so that SMEs can start operations and 
access  finance.  While  the  SME  Magna  Carta  formed  the  framework  for  the  overall  policy 
direction,  SMEs  still  face  a  policy  environment  that  is  not  adequately  supportive.  Major  policy 
issues to improve the investment climate, such as revisions to the incentive system, competition 
policies  expanded  to  more  sectors,  and  changes  to  the  tax  system  are  examined  in  the  ADB 
reports  Improving  the  Investment  Climate  in  the  Philippines  and  the  draft  Private  Sector 
Assessment  for  the  Philippines.  The  ADB  Southeast  Asia  Regional  Department  is  analyzing 
options  to  address  some  of  these  measures  under  a  broader  private  sector  development 
initiative.  However,  significant  targeted  policy  measures  also  have  a  direct  effect  on  the  SME 
enabling environment.  
 
13. 
A  number  of  surveys  have  revealed  that  SMEs  perceive  registration  and  licensing 
procedures  to  be  cumbersome  and  costly  with  the  process  taking  an  average  of  59  days  and 
requiring  11  procedures.  Furthermore,  they  cite  collateral  problems  as  hindering  access  to 
finance.8 Growth  and  export-oriented  SMEs  identify  insufficient  market  knowledge  and  market 
access  as  issues.  The  framework  for  registration  and  licensing  is  indeed  complicated.  Single 
proprietorships register with DTI, while partnerships and corporations register with the Securities 
and Exchange Commission (SEC). In addition, every enterprise needs to get a license from the 
local  government  unit  (LGU);  this  must  be  renewed  annually.  Registration  with  DTI  and  SEC 
serve  as  name  registration,  while  the  LGU  license  in  effect  allows  the  company  to  become 
operational  as  the  license  indicates  that  the  company  satisfies  all  national  and  LGU 
requirements  to  operate  in  its  respective  field.  The  LGUs  thus  have  the  most  reliable  data  on 
active  companies.  In  addition,  the  National  Internal  Revenue  Code  requires  all  business 
establishments to register with the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) to comply with the firm’s 
obligation  to  pay  national  income  taxes,  and  act  as  a  Government  withholding  tax  agent.  The 
SME  Development  Council  has  found  that  many  SMEs  register  with  DTI  solely  to  register  the 
business name, long before they start operations, which some never do. The SME Development 
Plan (Activity 48) calls for streamlining and facilitating registration and licensing processes.  
 
14. 
Because  of  the  variety  of  registering  agencies  and  the  separate  licensing  process,  no 
single  comprehensive  national  business  registry  serves  as  (i)  name  registration  for  the 
company,  (ii)  BIR  registry,  (iii)  repository  of  LGU  licensed  enterprises,  (iv)  registry  where 
financial  institutions  can  verify  loan  applications  from  companies,  (v)  data  source  for  the 
National  Statistics  Office,  and  (vi)  database  for  DTI  policymaking.  To  address  this,  the  SME 
Development Plan recommends development of the Philippine business registry (PBR) as one 
activity.  Now  designed,  the  registry  is  ready  to  be  established.  Implementation  will  be 
undertaken in phases, starting with the agencies involved, i.e., BIR, DTI, SEC, and major LGUs 
that have electronic systems and can interface with the other agencies. Over time, the registry 
will  be  linked  to  other  government  agencies  such  as  Department  of  Labor  and  Employment, 
National  Statistics  Office,  and  Social  Security  System.  The  PBR  is  envisaged  to  provide 
electronic  registration  and  submission  of  licensing  requests,  which  would  simplify  processes, 
lower  costs,  and  enhance  governance.  Thus  the  basic  requirements  for  SME  registration  and

2. 

Access to and Availability of Finance  

 
In  focus  group  discussions  for  the  recent  national  survey  on  SMEs  by  the  Employers 
16. 
Confederation of the Philippines and the International Labour Organization as well as a survey 
under  the  project  preparatory  TA,  business  owners  and  BDS  providers  described  access  to 
financing  as  the  most  pressing  constraint  facing  SMEs.  Access  to  commercial  banks  is 
particularly limited for small firms, which are able to source only 5–7% of their financing needs 
from  banks.  Most  SME  entrepreneurs  rely  on  family,  friends,  business  partners,  and  informal 
financing sources. In a survey of SMEs that have not accessed bank financing, inability to meet 
collateral requirements was the top constraint. While 92% of the 62 banks surveyed under the 
project  preparatory  TA  offered  short-term  working  capital  facilities  to  SMEs,  only  53%  offered 
fixed asset financing instruments. Access to trade and supplier financing is also limited.9 
 
17. 
Banks  perceive  SMEs  as  riskier  than  larger  firms  due  to  their  low  capital  base,  limited 
product lines leading to greater vulnerability to business cycle fluctuations, and vulnerability to 
deterioration  in  receivables  collections  or  loss  of  a  key  officer,  among  others.  SMEs  are  also 
perceived  to  have  weak  financial  discipline,  with  business  funds  often  mixed  with  the  owners’ 
personal  funds;  and  generally  to  have  weak  accounting  systems.  SMEs  rarely  use  banks  to 
manage  their  payroll  or  for  working  accounts,  and  the  bank-client  relationship  tends  to  be 
weaker than for medium to large companies. For the banks, each SME transaction is therefore 
costly,  as  it  generally  requires  more  staff  resources  in  relation  to  the  revenue  that  the  loan 
generates  compared  with  lending  to  larger  firms  with  which  the  bank  has  a  solid  bank-client 
relationship.  One  remedy  has  been  for  banks  to  only  accept  titled  real  estate  as  collateral, 
generally value it at 60% of appraised value, and set the loan floor at P1 million ($17,860), thus 
concentrating their SME lending to a certain market segment.

21. 
volume but in innovative products and outreach, thereby achieving a demonstration effect. SB 
Corporation  targets  underserved  SMEs  that  are  viable  but  cannot  access  bank  finance  and

During  preliminary  discussions  of  the  ADB  Private  Sector  Operations  Department 
(PSOD)  with  six  local  and  international  commercial  banks,  the  banks  expressed  interest  in 
expanding their SME lending portfolios beyond the legally mandated 8%. The renewed interest 
of  domestic  banks  in  the  SME  market  results  from  increased  competition  and  tight  margins  in 
the  large  borrower  segment,  as  well  as  BSP  regulatory  incentives  to  encourage  lending  to 
SMEs. However, domestic banks cite capital constraints and insufficient SME collateral as the 
main constraints to profitable expansion of their SME portfolio. An increased level of lending to 
SMEs  would  require  increased  capital,  but  problems  with  nonperforming  assets  limit  their 
options.  BSP  encourages  banks  to  remove  nonperforming  assets  to  free  up  resources  for 
lending and strengthen the banking system at large. Removing these assets, however, by sale 
to an asset management company is normally done at significantly discounted face value. This 
means  that  banks  have  to  realize  losses  that  in  turn  require  more  capital  to  meet  the  capital 
adequacy ratio requirement. Hence, banks that cannot raise sufficient capital may opt to reduce 
SME  lending  and  continue  to  invest  in  less  risky  assets,  and  only  slowly  deal  with  the 
nonperforming assets.  
 
25.

typically only titled real estate. Some SMEs lack this, and even though their revenues may be 
substantial (such as medium-size call centers) they have difficulty accessing finance based on 
cash flow alone. International banks would also like to diversify their loan portfolios to improve 
their  risk  profile  and  broaden  their  sources  of  revenue.  They  are  therefore  interested  in

Benefits and Impact  

A. 
 
The  SMEDSP,  associated  TA,  and  JFICT  project  are  expected  to  contribute  to  an

improved enabling environment for SMEs, a financially stronger SB Corporation better equipped 
to  expand  its  portfolio  at  the  wholesale  and  retail  level,  expanded  SME  lending  by  SB 
Corporation and commercial banks, improved access to credit information by banks and other 
credit providers, and increased SME growth and job creation by SMEs. SMEs are expected to 
benefit from better access to and augmented availability of finance. The project preparatory TA 
report  provided  estimates  based  on  previous  lending.  During  1994–1997  under  the  wholesale 
lending  window  P1  million  lent  generated  3.18  additional  jobs,  and  under  the  retail  window

calculation  indicates  at  least  3,500  and  1,800  additional  jobs  under  the  two  lending  windows 
respectively. However, any estimates can only give indicative figures given the variety of SMEs 
in  terms  of  labor  intensity.  Successful  project  implementation  will  result  in  increased  SME 
investments,  output,  exports,  and  employment;  but  exact  targets  for  each  variable  are  not 
realistic.  The  SMEDSP  will  be  effectively  complemented  by  other  development  programs 
targeted  at  BDS  (GTZ  and  Canadian  International  Development  Agency),  microenterprises 
(United States Agency for International Development), SMEs in the Visayas region (KfW), and 
possible further assistance by other development partners. A summary of poverty reduction and 
social strategy considerations is given in Appendix 11.

Current  projections  for  the  Philippines  indicate  an  average  4.9%  annual  real  gross  domestic

Corporation aims to capture the underserved segment of the SME market and has a policy to

strengthened through TA to ensure that credit expansion is undertaken in a prudent manner.

increase commitment to the credit program.

A nine-member board of directors governs SB Corporation, comprising a representative

officer who is also the chairs. The chair is responsible for overall operations of SB Corporation, 
assisted by a president and seven group heads. SB Corporation’s head office is in Makati City, 
Metro Manila; it has two regional offices in Cebu and Davao, and two representative offices in 
Luzon. Total number of employees is currently 138. As a GFI, SB Corporation is subject to the

On 16 November 2001, SB Corporation merged with the Guarantee Fund for Small and

B.  

Operations  

6. 
SB  Corporation’s  operations  cover  three  areas:  guarantees,  and  wholesale  and  retail 
SME  lending.  The  target  market  is  classified  into  three  groups  of  SMEs:  bankable,  nearly 
bankable,  and  prebankable  but  viable  SMEs.  For  bankable  SMEs,  the  SB  Corporation  offers 
wholesale  lending  facilities  to  help  SMEs  obtain  funding  from  the  formal  financial  sector  at 
reasonable  interest  rates  with  longer  payment  terms.  For  nearly  bankable  SMEs,  SB 
Corporation offers guarantee facilities allowing SMEs access to credit from the formal financial 
sector  by  securing  a  certain  percentage  of  the  loan  (up  to  85%).  For  prebankable  but  viable 
SMEs, SB Corporation provides direct loans for short-term receivables, purchase order and/or 
letter  of  credit  financing  as  well  as  working  capital  and  fixed  asset  financing.  Features  that 
differentiate  SB  Corporation’s  lending  from  banks  is  that  SB  Corporation  offers  smaller  loans, 
with  longer  repayment  terms  at  fixed  interest  rates.  In  terms  of  collateral,  SB  Corporation 
accepts a broader range of collateral (e.g., real estate, motor vehicles, receivables, purchasing 
orders,  and  corporate  guarantees)  compared  with  banks  that  mainly  accept  titled  prime  real 
estate lots. Collateral is valued at 64% of principal. This is in order to reach the target group of 
SMEs with smaller financing needs than commercial banks tend to accommodate. 
 
7. 
Guarantee operations started in 1992, and by 31 December 2003, SB Corporation had 
guaranteed  a  total  of  4,675  accounts  for  P8.66  billion.  Cumulative  guarantee  payments  from 
1993  to  2002  were  at  P101.64  million  ($1.8  million)  with  recoveries  of  P44.86  million  ($0.8 
million).  The  payments  represent  4.8%  of  total  guarantees  approved  and  issued  by  SB 
Corporation  for  the  same  period.  The  process  for  guarantees  is  as  follows.  Applications 
received  from  PFIs  are  reviewed  by  the  Credit  Guarantees  Group  at  SB  Corporation.  They 
undertake  a  second  due  diligence  of  the  application  and  if  complete  and  favorably  evaluated, 
the application is then sent to the Credit Committee for approval. The Credit Guarantees Group 
is seriously understaffed resulting in long processing times, and this, in combination with the fact 
that  SB  Corporation  does  not  have  a  sovereign  guarantee,  are  cited  by  banks  as  reasons  for 
their limited use of SB Corporation’s guarantee.  
 
8. 
The  wholesale  lending  window  was  introduced  in  1994.  SB  Corporation’s  board 
accredits  financial  institutions  if  they  meet  specified  criteria.  Financial  institutions  can  be 
accredited either through a fast-track or regular process. The fast-track process applies to the 
top 50% of expanded commercial banks in the Philippines and the top five commercial banks. 
The minimum criteria for these banks are (i) the bank must be in good standing with BSP and/or 
listed  at  the  Philippine  Stock  Exchange,  (ii)  have  a  satisfactory  track  record  of  dealing  with 
credits  with  other  GFIs,  (iii)  have  a  nonperforming  loan  ratio  below  20%,  and  (iv)  a  CAMELS3 
rating of 3 at BSP. All other banks are accredited through the regular process, which include a 
qualitative  evaluation  of  the  financial  institutions  performance  for  the  3  years  preceding 
accreditation. Ratios are calculated for profitability, collection efficiency, solvency, and liquidity. 
The qualitative evaluation includes assessments of (i) the management, board, and key offices; 
(ii)  ownership  structure;  (iii)  background  and  history  of  the  bank;  (iv)  compliance  BSP’s 
regulations on single borrower limits, DOSRI (director, officer, shareholder of the bankd or their 
related interests) rules, loan loss provisioning, and capitalization; (vi) compliance with the legally 
mandated lending to SMEs; and (vii) rate of lending activity. Accredited financial institutions then 
get  access  to  a  credit  line  for  onlending  to  SMEs  in  SB  Corporation’s  target  groups.  As  of 
January  2005,  30  PFIs  were  accredited  and  active.  Some  smaller  banks  reportedly  seek  SB 
Corporation  accreditation  more  as  a  seal  of  good  standing  than  as  a  means  to  augment  their 
lending  resources  and  thus  tend  to  make  limited  use  of  SB  Corporation’  wholesale  lending

Rationale.  The  introduction  of  market-based  products  to  enhance  the  channeling  of

innovation  supported  under  the  Project.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  partial  credit 
guarantee  (PCG)  facility,  which  in  partnership  with  selected  participating  financial  institutions 
(PFIs) shares the credit risks and rewards associated with SME lending, will raise the comfort 
level  of  PFIs  by  (i)  leveraging  the  PFIs’  resources,  (ii)  assisting  PFIs  to  develop  client 
relationships  with  SME  clients,  and  (iii)  introducing  good  practice  for  SME  lending  in  the 
Philippines.  The  PCG  facility  will  initially  draw  on  international  PFIs  (based  in  the  Philippines 
and  with  existing  experience  in  SME  lending  in  other  emerging  markets)  and  primarily  top  tier 
domestic PFIs that are accredited in the recently approved Trade Finance Facilitation Program1 
of ADB and that have both well-established underwriting procedures of an international standard 
and experience in similar lending methodologies. Once ADB has gained initial experience with 
the  PCG,  more  qualified  domestic  PFIs  are  expected  to  follow  the  first  tier  PFIs  and  develop 
similar methodologies for SME lending.2 
 
2. 
Objective  of  the  PCG  Facility.  The  objective  of  the  PCG  facility  under  the  Project  is 
twofold:  first,  to  leverage  through  a  market-based  approach  existing  financial  resources  of  the 
financial system for lending to an SME segment currently underserved by PFIs; and second, to 
provide  catalytic  support  for  innovative  financial  products  and  approaches  in  new  and  less 
familiar markets. Once successfully tested with PFIs, such products will be expanded among a 
larger  number  of  PFIs.  The  expected  outcome  of  the  PCG  facility  is  a  higher  volume  of  SME 
lending by commercial PFIs in Philippines.  
 
A. 

Facility Design 

3. 
Structure.  ADB will share the credit risk of SME loans with selected PFIs that are also 
participants in the Trade Finance Facilitation Program project and have been identified by ADB

agreed  portion  (up  to  50%)  of  the  SME  loan  portfolio.  The  PCGs  will  have  agreed  cover 
amounts and time frames to be selected following a due diligence process. The PCGs will detail 
the risk- and reward-sharing arrangements for individual loans within a defined portfolio of loans 
extended by the PFIs to SMEs. The loan portfolio covered under each PCG may be revolving, 
and the portfolio composition may change over time based on lending decisions of the PFI as 
agreed with ADB. ADB will not be involved in the lending decisions of the PFIs, but will agree 
with the PFIs on the lending selection criteria and risk management process. To underscore the 
market  approach,  the  PCG  facility  will  be  provided  through  ADB’s  private  sector  operations 
without government counterguarantee. Terms and conditions will be market based.

The Project will support the Philippine Government’s initiative to develop the Philippine business registry

establishments  under  different  authorities,  and  (ii)  a  service  tool  for  trade  and  business  development 
facilitation.  
 
The project has three phases: (i) phase I: the various business databases of Department of Trade and 
Industry (DTI) including those of the Board of Investments (BOI) will be upgraded and harmonized with 
the  business  registration  system  of  the  Securities  Exchange  Commission;  (ii)  phase  II:  the  integrated

LGUs  and  e-ready  organizations  such  as  Department  of  Labor  and  Employment,  Philippine  Health 
Insurance  Corporation,  and  one-stop  business  centers  such  as  small  and  medium  enterprise  (SME) 
centers will be increased. A business facilitation system will be developed as an integral complementary 
function of the PBR, and installed in SME centers and LGUs as the delivery channels in this phase.  
 
The  project  will  (i)  improve  governance  by  reducing  discretional  manual  processes  in  business 
registration; (ii) enhance the efficiency of business registration procedures through interfacing DTI system 
with  other  systems;  (iii)  improve  the  policymaking,  monitoring,  and  marketing  functions  of  the 
Government using  a knowledge management  tool  to  generate  various statistical  and  analytical  reports; 
(iv) promote business opportunities within domestic and international trade through a business facilitation 
platform;  and  (v)  help  business  enterprises  lower  their  operational  costs  by  streamlining  submission  of 
information to various Government agencies and others. 
 
PBR  is  in  line  with  the  e-government  Initiatives,  which  will  apply  information  and  communication 
technology to various government projects to enhance the quality and efficiency of government services 
to  the  public  and  the  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  2004–2010,  which  calls  for  efficient

agenda of President Arroyo on item 1, 5, and 7, namely job creation, developing digital infrastructure, and
